On November 1, 2017 Hamas handed over control of its five border crossings to the Palestinian Authority, the first of many changes to take shape within Gaza following the reconciliation deal signed last month on October 12. The next benchmark will be President Mahmoud Abbas’ first visit to Gaza in ten years sometime this month. Abbas is due to participate in discussions on how once dueling factions, Hamas and Fatah, will unite under a single banner—and to steer a process for elections.
I could visit the Gaza strip but I think that Israel could forbid him to visit Gaza .
Significant progress with Fatah; Abbas admin indicates visit- must build on relationship and demonstrate seriousness of commitment
PA controls only 5% of Gaza. PA has not lifted sanctions or rationing of power to Gaza. Hamas has not disarmed. PA continues to cooperate with Israel on Security. No real change. Not going.

It appears from news reports that the unity agreement will not advance significantly toward implementation within this timeframe. And even if it did then Abbas would have to weigh safety concerns and time constraints with the benefits of a fresh showing of solidarity. I'm leaving only a token weight for remote possibilities.

Capturing links for later analysis. Current primary belief driving forecast is that Abbas wants his visit to be the capstone to reconciliation (see [4] below). Don't get the sense that we're near a "capstone" moment.
No positive results from the negotiations this month. Peace treaty isn’t favored by US and IS without more concessions.  Uncertain about outcome makes it unlikely for a visit.

A lot of issues need to be ironed out.  Agreement on elections in 2018 is one step forward. However I don’t think Abbas visits if actual practical control of Gaza isn’t first ceded by the Hamas military wing to the PA. Hard to see a trip coming to fruition in the time remaining for the question.

It is actually quite remarkable that even now, more than a month after the original reconciliation document was signed in Cairo, the PA still has not lifted those sanctions — the same sanctions that make it difficult to supply electricity to the Gaza Strip, that sent thousands of former PA officials into early retirement, and that prevent the transfer of payments for medical treatment and the purchase of medications for Gaza’s residents. This is why Hamas and Egypt suspect so strongly that the PA is deliberately dragging its feet and has no genuine intention of reaching true reconciliation.
As time is running out for the 1 January deadline, the likelyhood of a visit is quite low.

Decreasing for 2 reasons. 
1. less than 40 days left. 
2. Despite the recent announcement of joint elections by the end of 2018, the reconciliation talks in Cairo have not gone well.  
From Salah Bardawil, a member of Hamas’s political bureau: Bardawil said, "We acted as best we could on all issues with the Palestinian Authority, but there is a great feeling of a missed opportunity.” He described the agreement as “meaningless and without real mechanisms for implementation. There is a vague joint declaration, but I find it difficult to see how we will succeed in bringing it into expression on the ground." Bardawil accused Fatah representatives of backing down from commitments in previous summits, leading to the current situation. "The American pressure and the threats from Israel adversely affected the Palestinian Authority during the talks," he charged. https://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/238398

Needless to say, there is a lot of work that needs to be done until Abbas would risk a visit.

Given that he made his resignation announcement what apparently in captivity in Riyadh, one may suspect that his un-resignation has to do with getting support from other world leaders to protect him, his family, and his nation.

Chances are better than average with the deal signed, watching to see what happens at the meeting in Cairo on November 21st. Somewhat expecting Abbas to comment directly on a visit.

Visit is unlikely so quickly, especially now that the Saudis are interacting with The Palestinians re. Lebanon.

A visit is very likely with view to declaring authority, but not that soon. The political latitude required for Abbas to establish control dictates a longer-term negotiation and the clock is ticking very fast. A visit before 1 Jan 2018 could be seen as hasty and possibly interpreted as a weakness.

Will Mahmoud Abbas visit Gaza before 1 January 2018? What would it take for Abbas to revisit Gaza? What would it take for him to not revisit Gaza? What about security conditions? For years now it has been said Abbas was going to be visiting Gaza “very soon” but as of Nov 2017 he still hasn’t revisited. Hamas won’t give up its weapons so Abbas may take that into account for not visiting. One Hamas terrorist could take out Abbas in order to provoke a renewed war between Hamas and Fatah. Plus Abbas hasn’t lifted the sanctions against Gaza. Don’t expect Hamas to relinquish complete control even though an agreement was signed between Hamas and Fatah to restore the PA’s governing authority in Gaza. Therefore Abbas is almost certainly not going to visit Gaza before Jan 2018.

Time ebbs away fast. Meanwhile, the alliance between Israel and Saudi Arabia just became more public, and the common threat uniting these frenemies is Iran, the top ally of Hamas, which controls Gaza. Would Abbas find an advantage to setting foot inside the epicenter of this soap opera in the next few weeks? Lowering probability.

Looks like Hamas fooled me with their political theater. They're not serious about reconciliation after all. Thanks to JakePettit2 for his analysis.

1. Likelihood of this deal coming to fruition in terms of a meaningful transfer of administrative power from Hamas to the PA is nearly zero:
-Obstacle #1: Hamas has strongly declared that it will not disband its 25,000+ strong military arm (Qassam brigade) https://www.haaretz.com/middle-east-news/palestinians/1.818235. Huge problem for the reality of a transfer-of-power from Hamas to the PA. The PA still maintains its policy of paying pre-2007 Fatah government workers and police officers to not work for Hamas, and will have to form a new administrative government as Hamas has dissolved its "administrative committee." The expectations inside Gaza, however, still revolve around a power-sharing agreement (Sami Abdel-Shafi, an independent political consultant in Gaza City, says, "In the West Bank some people are talking about a complete governmental takeover in Gaza, whereas within Hamas, the language being used is all about political power sharing.") Besides, what does Fatah-controlled administration really mean or really look like if Hamas maintains 20-25,000 soldiers inside Gaza?

The integration of the factions will be a slow, carefully planned process, with Abbas maybe visiting later down the line. The reconciliation deal surprised many, though its future implications are clear. https://www.timesofisrael.com/hamas-pragmatism-in-gaza-handover-hints-at-a-new-future-for-the-strip/. https://www.timesofisrael.com/how-do-you-solve-a-problem-like-palestinian-reconciliation-slowly-if-at-all/

The baseline by @joew92 (the number of visits since 2007) I think is the wrong baseline.  It’s important to take the outside view here--it's not the number of his visits in the past seven years but rather what is the baseline number of visits of heads of state after a major peace process or deal?  This is probably pretty high (think Ireland, Columbia and FARC, any major peace process or treaty like between the US and the Soviet Union).  I'd place this at 90% and higher.  There are some international events that are just so big and important that heads of state have to be present, the ceremony matters a lot.  I think in this case, a visit by Abbas, should be expected.

Not convinced it’s impossible though, so I’m still going to stay above the current 10% consensus.
